<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GAMING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/22/california-sues-gaming-company-activision-blizzard?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Activision Blizzard Gets Its Stats Checked
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/22/california-sues-gaming-company-activision-blizzard?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Sign on facade of office of videogame publisher Activision in the Silico..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODc5L2FjdGl2aXNpb24uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Smith Collection/gado/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">California legislators sued video game developer Activision Blizzard yesterday, citing its “pervasive ‘frat boy’ culture” and mistreatment of women employees.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Following a two-year investigation into the company (which you might know for making <em>Call of Duty</em> and <em>World of Warcraft</em>), the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH) claims that female employees—who make up 20% of Activision Blizzard’s workforce of about 9,500—were routinely <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/video-games/california-sues-activision-blizzard-alleged-sexual-harassment-frat-boy-rcna1487?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">discriminated against</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The details</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Women employees were underpaid, promoted “more slowly,” and terminated “more quickly” than their male coworkers, the suit alleges. One complainant said her manager denied her a promotion, and when asked why, was told it was because “she might get pregnant and like being a mom too much.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The “underpaid” part especially stings considering Activision’s CEO Bobby Kotick was the </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/article/who-are-the-highest-paid-ceos-2021-719ad52ec522a79baf9870cd2bc73f1d?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">second-highest paid</a></span><span> CEO in the S&P 500 last year, according to the AP. And despite a 50% pay cut, the FT reports he’ll make </span><span><a href="https://www.thegamer.com/activision-blizzard-ceo-bobby-kotick-155-million/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">roughly the same</a></span><span> amount this year due to equity payouts. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Allegations of sexual discrimination included verbal and physical advances from male coworkers in the workplace. The suit details that one female employee died by suicide on a corporate trip after nude photos were leaked and shared among male colleagues who had previously harassed her.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Activision’s response?</strong> Denial on all fronts. The company told NPR, "The DFEH includes distorted, and in many cases false, descriptions of Blizzard's past,” and insists the environment described “is not the Blizzard workplace of today."</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Not just a glitch</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The video game industry has a reputation for gender inequality and outright sexism in its games, gaming communities (remember <a href="https://gawker.com/what-is-gamergate-and-why-an-explainer-for-non-geeks-1642909080?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Gamergate</a>?), and even corporate headquarters. Along with Activision Blizzard, at least two other companies have come under fire over their workplace cultures:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Riot Games (</span><span><em>League of Legends</em></span><span>, </span><span><em>Valorant</em></span><span>) was sued in 2018 over gender discrimination after a Kotaku report </span><span><a href="https://www.polygon.com/2021/2/9/22274969/riot-games-lawsuit-gender-discrimination-sexual-harassment-ceo?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revealed</a></span><span> its “bro culture.” </span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Ubisoft (</span><span><em>Assassin’s Creed</em></span><span>, </span><span><em>Far Cry</em></span><span>) was </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-07-21/ubisoft-sexual-misconduct-scandal-harassment-sexism-and-abuse?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">accused</a></span><span> of rampant sexism and racism last summer.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The lawsuit against Activision Blizzard shows that the #MeToo movement is still reaching its crescendo in the video game industry.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HOUSING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/22/us-housing-market-frenzy-may-peaked?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Housing Market May Have Peaked
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/22/us-housing-market-frenzy-may-peaked?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="An illustration of the wooden frame of a house in front of a lavender background. In front of the house is a red sign with four $ printed on it." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80NzQ0L2x1bWJlcl9wcmljZXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Before you offer $100k over asking price on a new home, you should hear this: The boiling US housing market took a refreshing dip in the pool in June. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yes, the US median house price did hit a record high of <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/median-existing-home-price-hit-new-high-in-june-11626963073?mod=hp_lead_pos1" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$363,300</a> last month, up 22.9% from a year earlier. But median home prices are a lagging indicator—June’s data is based on contracts signed in April and May. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">More supply is coming onto the market.</strong> More owners listed their homes last month after they saw home seekers offering things like crypto in order to secure the deed. The inventory of houses for sale at the end of June was <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/22/sales-of-existing-homes-rise-slightly-as-more-listings-finally-hit-the-market.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">1.25 million</a>, a slight improvement from May. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I don’t believe you’ll see the kinds of [price] increases you’ve seen in the last 12 months,” Sheryl Palmer, a home-builder executive, told the WSJ. “That’s not sustainable.”</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> Despite some cooling off, strong demand and ultra-low mortgage rates will still keep the housing market competitive in the months to come, experts say. </p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENERGY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/22/startup-announces-breakthrough-technology-energy-storage?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
A Potential Game Changer in Energy Storage
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/22/startup-announces-breakthrough-technology-energy-storage?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="A charging battery" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=447 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/bL7MlTR55rT87QYqj9/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="A charging battery" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/bL7MlTR55rT87QYqj9/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On the journey to greater adoption of renewables, it’s not enough to make the energy...you’ve got to <em>hold </em>the energy. But how to do so cheaply and at scale remains one of the biggest challenges facing the industry.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Form Energy, a startup backed by Bill Gates and Jeff Bezos, might have cracked the code: <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/startup-claims-breakthrough-in-long-duration-batteries-11626946330?mod=hp_lead_pos4" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">batteries made from iron</a> that can hold electricity for days or even weeks. Form’s batteries may be key to achieving President Biden’s goal of a carbon-free power grid in the US by 2035.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture</strong>: Many utilities use lithium-ion batteries, similar to those in Teslas, to ensure a steady power supply. But they typically store electricity for just four-to-six hours at a time and cost an eye-watering $50–$80 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) of storage. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Where Form Energy comes in</strong>: Just like your middle school science fair’s potato battery, Form Energy’s iron-air batteries only use the simplest materials: iron, air and a water-based electrolyte. It claims the cost will run lower than $20/kWh, a price point at which experts think renewables could viably replace fossil fuel plants.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead</strong>…Form Energy <a href="https://formenergy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Form-Energy_-GREPilotPress-Release.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced</a> it would partner with a Minnesota utility to test its battery, which the company says can deliver continuous power for 150 hours.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here’s something you already know but we’re going to tell you anyway: it’s possible for your kid to be online <em>even more</em>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As schools continue to be more digital than ever, accessing new websites and online tools is as necessary as the textbooks in your child’s backpack.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So before your kid attends their next online VR augmented reality laser light astronomy show for course credit (somehow), <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N9037.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26095219.308188064;dc_trk_aid=501158817;dc_trk_cid=154149272;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Opt-in to Cyber Safety</a>.</p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/22/key-performance-indicators-july-23?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="TOKYO, JAPAN - JULY 22: Simone Biles of the United States during the Art..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODgxL3RoZV9vbHltcGljX2dhbWVzLXRva3lvXzIuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Tim Clayton - Corbis/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>With the International Olympic Committee <a href="https://apnews.com/article/2020-tokyo-olympics-sports-basketball-czech-republic-olympic-team-slovakia-olympic-team-8172b7008b465652f4fb7f1333fa5249?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">adding 18 new events</a> to the Tokyo Games, women’s participation will be at 49%, the highest it’s ever been. In Paris in 1900, when women made their Olympic debut, 22 women participated out of 997 athletes total. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“I think we will effectively transition from people seeing us as primarily being a social media company to being a metaverse company.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facebook: First a place to rate hotness, then a social media behemoth, and finally...a “metaverse” company, if Mark Zuckerberg has his way. The CEO <a href="https://www.theverge.com/22588022/mark-zuckerberg-facebook-ceo-metaverse-interview?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">explained</a> what that means in an interview with The Verge.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Listen: </strong>A look back at the Harlem Cultural Festival of 1969 with Questlove. (<a href="https://www.listennotes.com/podcasts/object-of-sound/summer-of-soul-feat-questlove-JixCmSyFvH9/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Object of Sound</em></a>)</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">From the minds that brought you the Greatest Product of All Time and bitcoin in the Markets section comes the Business Olympiad, which seeks to find answers to the deepest, darkest questions in the business world.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Questions like:<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>Which fast-food chain <em>actually </em>makes the tastiest chicken sandwich? What is the most successful fictional company? And what is the biggest business flameout of all time and why is it MoviePass? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How it works: </strong>With the help of you, the wise Morning Brew reader, we’ll award gold, silver, and bronze medals across 10 “events” over the next two weeks. Voting for the Business Olympiad starts on Monday and will take place on the Brew’s social platforms. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/22/business-olympiad?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Check out the field here</a> and get ready to cast your vote. </p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

</table>

style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eSmith Collection/gado/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCalifornia legislators sued video game developer Activision Blizzard yesterday, citing its “pervasive ‘frat boy’ culture” and mistreatment of women employees.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFollowing a two-year investigation into the company (which you might know for making \u003cem\u003eCall of Duty\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eWorld of Warcraft\u003c/em\u003e), the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH) claims that female employees—who make up 20% of Activision Blizzard’s workforce of about 9,500—were routinely \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/video-games/california-sues-activision-blizzard-alleged-sexual-harassment-frat-boy-rcna1487?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ediscriminated against\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe details\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWomen employees were underpaid, promoted “more slowly,” and terminated “more quickly” than their male coworkers, the suit alleges. One complainant said her manager denied her a promotion, and when asked why, was told it was because “she might get pregnant and like being a mom too much.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe “underpaid” part especially stings considering Activision’s CEO Bobby Kotick was the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/who-are-the-highest-paid-ceos-2021-719ad52ec522a79baf9870cd2bc73f1d?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esecond-highest paid\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e CEO in the S\u0026P 500 last year, according to the AP. And despite a 50% pay cut, the FT reports he’ll make \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.thegamer.com/activision-blizzard-ceo-bobby-kotick-155-million/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eroughly the same\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e amount this year due to equity payouts. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAllegations of sexual discrimination included verbal and physical advances from male coworkers in the workplace. The suit details that one female employee died by suicide on a corporate trip after nude photos were leaked and shared among male colleagues who had previously harassed her.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eActivision’s response?\u003c/strong\u003e Denial on all fronts. The company told NPR, \"The DFEH includes distorted, and in many cases false, descriptions of Blizzard's past,” and insists the environment described “is not the Blizzard workplace of today.\"\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eNot just a glitch\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe video game industry has a reputation for gender inequality and outright sexism in its games, gaming communities (remember \u003ca href=\"https://gawker.com/what-is-gamergate-and-why-an-explainer-for-non-geeks-1642909080?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGamergate\u003c/a\u003e?), and even corporate headquarters. Along with Activision Blizzard, at least two other companies have come under fire over their workplace cultures:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eRiot Games (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eLeague of Legends\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eValorant\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e) was sued in 2018 over gender discrimination after a Kotaku report \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.polygon.com/2021/2/9/22274969/riot-games-lawsuit-gender-discrimination-sexual-harassment-ceo?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erevealed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e its “bro culture.” \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eUbisoft (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eAssassin’s Creed\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eFar Cry\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e) was \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-07-21/ubisoft-sexual-misconduct-scandal-harassment-sexism-and-abuse?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaccused\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e of rampant sexism and racism last summer.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe lawsuit against Activision Blizzard shows that the #MeToo movement is still reaching its crescendo in the video game But median home prices are a lagging indicator—June’s data is based on contracts signed in April and May. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMore supply is coming onto the market.\u003c/strong\u003e More owners listed their homes last month after they saw home seekers offering things like crypto in order to secure the deed. The inventory of houses for sale at the end of June was \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/22/sales-of-existing-homes-rise-slightly-as-more-listings-finally-hit-the-market.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e1.25 million\u003c/a\u003e, a slight improvement from May. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“I don’t believe you’ll see the kinds of [price] increases you’ve seen in the last 12 months,” Sheryl Palmer, a home-builder executive, told the WSJ. “That’s not sustainable.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e Despite some cooling off, strong demand and ultra-low mortgage rates will still keep the housing market competitive in the months to come, experts say. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn the journey to greater adoption of renewables, it’s not enough to make the energy...you’ve got to \u003cem\u003ehold \u003c/em\u003ethe energy. But how to do so cheaply and at scale remains one of the biggest challenges facing the industry.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eForm Energy, a startup backed by Bill Gates and Jeff Bezos, might have cracked the code: \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/startup-claims-breakthrough-in-long-duration-batteries-11626946330?mod=hp_lead_pos4\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebatteries made from iron\u003c/a\u003e that can hold electricity for days or even weeks. Form’s batteries may be key to achieving President Biden’s goal of a carbon-free power grid in the US by 2035.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture\u003c/strong\u003e: Many utilities use lithium-ion batteries, similar to those in Teslas, to ensure a steady power supply. But they typically store electricity for just four-to-six hours at a time and cost an eye-watering $50–$80 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) of storage. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhere Form Energy comes in\u003c/strong\u003e: Just like your middle school science fair’s potato battery, Form Energy’s iron-air batteries only use the simplest materials: iron, air and a water-based electrolyte. It claims the cost will run lower than $20/kWh, a price point at which experts think renewables could viably replace fossil fuel plants.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead\u003c/strong\u003e…Form Energy \u003ca href=\"https://formenergy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Form-Energy_-GREPilotPress-Release.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e it would partner with a Minnesota utility to test its battery, which the company says can deliver continuous power for 150
